audio_caption: The clip begins with a conversation between two speakers. A man initiates the dialogue, referencing a previous discussion in December about the bitcoin market, mentioning its value at the time. He adopts a neutral tone, recalling a previous statement indicating belief that price changes were temporary. The man then shifts to a more inquisitive tone, observing that the price has increased, and raises the question of whether it might be another price fluctuation that will decrease soon.

The audio features a single male speaker enthusiastically discussing Bitcoin, predicting it will reach $250,000 by 2022 or 2023. He believes that while other currencies fluctuate against it, Bitcoin remains constant and they will eventually become useless.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing a future where credit card transaction fees are reduced, stating, "I see a future where we don't have to pay the credit card companies 2.5 to 4% every time we buy something." He then corrects himself, clarifying that it's the banks, not the credit card companies, that "are the ones who are ganging, trying to gang up and get rid of Bitcoin." This statement is followed by someone off-mic speaking softly.

The audio clip starts with a male speaker discussing blockchain and its potential impact on accounting, noting its transparency and the likely reactions of accountants who might feel threatened. The speaker believes technology usually prevails and sees blockchain as a great technology that will benefit everyone. No background sounds are present in the clip.

The audio clip features a male speaker who uses a conversational tone as he predicts fluctuations in Bitcoin's market share, suggesting it will reach at least 5% by 2022 or 2023, potentially making a single Bitcoin token worth $250,000. His prediction seems conservative according to him.

The audio begins with a male speaker summarizing an economist's argument about the security of Bitcoin versus fiat currency, mentioning that "if you lose your credit card details, then you can still get refunded," but if a private key is stolen, crypto funds are "gone forever." He then asks, "What do you think about it?"

The audio clip begins with a male speaker disputing something, stating, "For one thing, he's wrong" and claiming that "no bank is responsible for refunding your money" above $250,000. He further states, "The Bitcoin blockchain has never been hacked" while asserting that banks are frequently hacked and constantly "playing whack-a-mole" to keep hackers away, as their technology gets older. The speaker's tone is assertive and argumentative.

The audio clip features a male speaker confidently discussing the security and rising popularity of Bitcoin's blockchain technology, noting that it has never been hacked. He also mentions improvements being made by engineers and a shift away from traditional banking. The speaker concludes by suggesting that the best security will be with Bitcoin.

The audio clip features a single male speaker who seems to be criticizing economists. The speaker describes that most economists he knows have written their book, and they don't want to change it, even though what they should be saying is, "Wow, this is so cool". He complains that they are sticking to their original teachings and beliefs, instead of embracing the transformation of the economic system. The speaker suggests that these people have a vested interest in keeping things the way they are. He then says that progress moves ahead, and they're going to have to adapt, so he tells them to write another book.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker introducing a discussion about Libra, Facebook's cryptocurrency. The speaker notes the mixed reactions, excitement, and concerns about privacy. He then asks for an opinion on the project. Another male speaker responds positively to innovation but raises concerns about Libra compared to Bitcoin. He believes that while Bitcoin is tested, Libra is new and has risks. He also worries about Libra's centralized nature versus the decentralized aspect of new currencies. The second male speaker continues to emphasize the trust one needs to place in Facebook and its leaders, questioning the reliability of Facebook leadership if Mark Zuckerberg were to leave.

The audio clip features a single male speaker advocating for Bitcoin over Libra, stating he prefers a currency that is "tried and true," "battle tested," decentralized, open, transparent, and global. His tone is assertive and persuasive. The clip concludes.

The clip starts with a conversation, where a speaker asks about crypto projects in which someone would invest. Then, another speaker shares that they invested in Open Node to allow bitcoin to be spent easily, as well as in different decentralized technologies. This speaker mentions gun or party as examples. They believe decentralized bandwidth will be powerful. They also talk about a company called unstoppable, which is decentralized websites or social media. The speaker concludes by describing this media as impossible to be censored by the government.

The clip starts with a conversation where a man is being asked about his vetting process, he replies by saying that a lot of it has to do with the team and the technology. He adds that the technology has to be unique, open, and new to get his attention. The speaker continues, emphasizing that the project needs to bring a fundamental change to the world. He concludes by saying that he is not interested in another token centralized around a company or people, but in something new.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing tokens, particularly if "it's a token that's extremely good with smart contracts" and the potential interest in contracts that have been built. He shifts to considering a token that makes Bitcoin "an easy system for whatever," suggesting that if a token achieves this, "you've got a chance". A musical chord plays at the end of the recording.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing Anthony Pompliano's investment in Bitcoin.  Following this, a second male speaker responds, stating "I have no idea" and "when you count your money it's time to sell everything." He talks about his investment strategy and uses Bitcoin for rent and university fees.

The audio clip begins with a confident male voice stating "we accept Bitcoin for anything." Another male speaker with a casual tone urges listeners to subscribe if they want to know when Bitcoin will reach the moon. This is followed by a brief advertisement from Coin Telegraph with a perky female voice saying "like, subscribe, and huddle." Then, a musical interlude takes over with ambient, somewhat eerie, electronic music.
